22680894.review:
The type of game you see video of and buy within the hour.
Also the type of game where you look up and realize it's 3 am. (I've played a lot more than Steam thinks I have.)

=Premise=
Engineer steampunk war vehicles and fortifications. Then make them fight.

=Execution=
Gameplay is simple and intuitive, yet deep, and already offers lots for players to learn and play with.

Building: Every part has pros and cons, and, as the designer, you can easily spend hours upon hours refining a creation to be sleek and efficient. Or you can make a giant wall of cannons. In addition, you can paint and decorate your creations to make sure they look good on the battlefield.

Combat: Exciting and fun (it's the big payoff after the building phase), though it can be a little clunky and buggy at the moment. (The game is still in alpha after all!) The combat system is quite deep, and well balanced with the building system. The compromises you make in the building phase absolutely define the tactics you use in the combat phase, though placement and use of terrain can also make or break a battle.

=Impression=
Already one of my favorite games to date, up alongside Minecraft and XCOM.
I can't wait to see it grow and mature.

I rarely write reviews, however, as the game was just SO MUCH FUN TO PLAY, and the Devs asked nicely, I will give my 2 cents worth:
At first, I was somewhat turned off by the pixelated graphics. I actually put it away for a couple of months thinking, Meh! Another game bought on sale thats kinda crappy.
One quiet afternoon, I got a wild hair up my ass and decided to wade through the tutorial. Woah, Dude...this game rocks! Every Dev who has decided to build a game needs to review Airships to understand what is missing from a CRAP LOAD of games today; i.e. PLAYABILITY. Games CAN be fun wiothout supedoopa graphics taxing your GPU.
That being said, would I have preferred non-pixelated graphics? Well, Yeah! But that is on me and my own feelings toward the retro trend of 8-bit style games. I got plenty of time with my Atari 2600 back in the day to suit me ...
I am not going to replicate what others have said regarding how the game is played, however, if you enjoy War Games, Sim,ulations, Shooting, Management, and General Sandbox Building-type games, buy this title. You will not regret the purchase at double the asking price. Trust me, I've bought my share of egg-laying Steam games that have to be refunded or just lay dormant in my collection. 
Lastly, I would like to thank anyone who had anything to do with bringing this game to market.

22461774.review:
Airships is an interesting game that combines RTS with engineering to make a unique battle experience. Creating different grades of craft for different situations prooves challeneging, as the conquest portion of the game, the enemy is always trying to one up you. It's an arms race to build the biggest guns first, but often creators need to think more than just about firepower. Budgets and requirements to keep a ship running shift the balance in the skies, and it is as much a puzzle game as an RTS when it comes to building.

This said, the game is still in Early Access, so there's a slight lack of content. The conquest mode doesn't last very long on any difficulty, and beyond these short campaigns, there is only the designer, non-campaign combat, and multiplayer. Additionally, it is worth noting that the campaign is very simplistic. Hopefully the creators will try to strive for additional content and game modes as the game becomes more popular. On the upside, this game is Workshop enabled, and people have already added a lot of fantastic content, so until there's more official stuff we have the brilliant work of modders to keep us busy.

7.5/10

22382368.review:
If you came looking for a review, I'm afraid you came to the wrong place.
If you are, however, looking for a delicious pie recipe, then I have just the thing for you!



[b]Ingredients[/b]


For the base
[list]
 [*]   60g butter, melted, plus extra for greasing
 [*]   15 digestive biscuit
 [*]   85g crunchy peanut butter
[/list]
For the filling
[list]
[*]    200g crème fraîche
[*]    200g full-fat cream cheese
[*]    25g icing sugar, sifted
[*]    ½ tsp vanilla paste, or seeds from ½ vanilla pod
[/list]
For the sauce and topping
[list]
[*]    450g ripe strawberry (smaller sized ones are best)
[*]    2 tbsp icing sugar, plus extra for dusting
[*]    40g peanut brittle bar, crushed (we used a Mr Tom bar, but you could also use a slab of peanut brittle from a sweet shop)
[/list]

[b]Method[/b]

[olist]
[*]     Generously grease a 20cm round sandwich tin and line the base with parchment. Finely crush the biscuits, either in a processor or by putting them into a food bag, squeezing out the air, then bashing with a rolling pin.

[*]     Work the butter and peanut butter into the biscuits until the mix looks like wet sand. Using the back of a cutlery spoon, press the mix evenly over the base and up the sides of the tin. Once even, go over the crumbs again, pressing and firming to a smooth crust. Chill in the freezer for 30 mins.

[*]     Beat the filling ingredients together with electric hand beaters until thick. Spoon carefully into the biscuit case, then top with about 25 strawberries. Chill for at least 2 hrs. For the sauce, use a hand blender or processor to purée 200g strawberries with the icing sugar until smooth.

[*]     When ready to serve, carefully push the very cold pie up out of the tin (standing it on something like an upturned mug will help). Sprinkle over the peanut brittle and extra icing sugar. Serve with the sauce.

[/olist]

22109502.review:
[h1]You Can't Take The Skies From Me![/h1]

[b]Disclosure:  I received a key for this game as part of the review panel for the A MAZE games festival.[/b]

[b]Airships: Conquer the Skies = Dickensian Steampunk World War + FTL + Pixel Piracy + Gratuitous Space Battles[/b]

This is, at the time of this review, an Early Access title with some definite rough edges.  However, it is already a very playable game that, although somewhat Spartan (See: Starkly functional, not kicking people into pits) in it's presentation don't let that fool you.  There is quite a bit going on under the hood.

The theme reminds me of World War I scaling combined with H.G. Wells-like steampunk and fanciful technology with just a little sprinkling of fantasy in there.  The world is locked in bleak war with giant airships and landships at the front of the battle.  Rather than helium, your airships are held aloft with "suspendium", either as a dust in balloons or as a sort of engine housed in the ship's interior.

Ship design is an interesting balance between weight, lift, propulsion, durability, crew requirements, and cost.  Sure, you could sacrifice some armor to drop some weight and add an extra weapon, but you risk going up like a matchstick if you do.  Or perhaps you want to build a secondary suspendium chamber for extra lift and redundancy in case the other one is taken out?  Good idea, but remember that you need coal to power the various functions of your ship, which means more modules, more weight, more cost.

You also can design "land ships" which is pretty much the same as designing an airship sans lift components.  Instead you have a selection of mech-like legs and tank-like tracks to choose from.  They don't have the advantage of flight, but this also means weight isn't quite as much of a concern and they can make great, heavily-armored, mobile anti-air platforms as a result.

Lastly, you can also design non-mobile buildings as the centerpieces of defense in your territories.  You can really stack on the armor and weaponry there.  Just be sure you design the building to be resistant against fire, invasion, and attacks from multiple angles! Careful though, every module in this game has weight and physics and it's a huge disaster if parts of your structures begin to collapse on themselves!

There is a campaign to be played which is at the moment extremely simplistic but fun.  You send spies to neighboring states so that you can see their defenses.  Then you pay to sabotage them or build up your forces enough to overcome theirs and then invade.  As you control more territitories you gain more income, technology, and ship building ports.  Ships have upkeep costs to consider, and you need to budget your secret police (to prevent enemies from sabotaging you).  There isn't much to it other than that.

The game really expressly shines in the design and combat aspects.  The interface for design is a little bit cumbersome, but doesn't detract from the fun of snapping together modules on a grid.  There is also a bit of a personal touch there as you create unique shapes and decorate the ships with paint, banners, and decals.  You can then test your designs against the AI (or pit AI against AI) in the sandbox combat arena.

The combat itself can be pretty exciting despite how simple the game looks.  The way your crew operates reminds me a lot of FTL without the micromanagement.  That is to say that your little air sailors really do move around the ship and man the various stations, but you don't control them directly.  When you give the order to move, the crew runs to take coal from your coal stores and shovel them into the engine.  When you fire on a target, some sailors man the weapons while others haul up ammo.  Fires break out and sailors scramble to put them out with water, etc.  As you lose sailors in battle this diminishes your capabilty to run your ship efficiently, or can often leave you dead in the skies.

Combat is impactful, with holes being punched through armor, and entire sections of your ships being blasted apart.  Fires break out and burn out of control.  Boarders scramble in through your windows using their tiny little grappling hooks.  Battering rams smash you to pieces.  It's all pretty intense and battles rarely play out the exact same way twice.  Sometimes a very lucky shot is all it takes to entirely turn the tide.  Other times what seems like a bad thing - like your ship falling out of the sky - might end up a good thing, like that falling ship absolutely squashing an enemy ship that was unlucky enough to be underneath it.

There is multiplayer here but in an extremely limited fashion (EG - no multiplayer campaigns), but that could possibly change down the road as this game is still under development.

[i]Fire up the suspendium chamber if you...[/i]

[list]
[*] Are looking for a creative tactical combat game.
[*] Love building and iterating designs.
[*] Are a fan of all things steampunk and airship.
[/list]

[i]All hands abandon ship if you...[/i]

[list]
[*] Really want a lot of flashy visuals.
[*] Prefer a lot of micro-management or direct control.
[*] Desire deep multiplayer.
[/list]

[u]The Bottom Line[/u]

This game was a delightful surprise for an Early Access title.  It offers quite a bit of meat at the current stage of things, and is what I would call "fully playable".  I've already sunk many hours mostly just designing ships and combat scenarios alone.

With that said, there are some definite improvements that I'd love to see.  First in my mind are the landships.  Unless they are absurdly large, they are sort of ironically terrible at traveling on land.  This makes them far less generally useful than airships.

Also some aspects of design likewise seem entirely more useful than others.  Other than in cheap, small, suicide attacker airships, I found that using suspendium dust balloons is of pretty dubious use other than as a supplemental means of lift to suspendium chambers.  They are always targeted first by AI and are destroyed very easily.  So creating a giant Zeppelin-like craft or a Final Fantasy style airship isn't terribly feasible.

It'd be great to see traditional matchmaking for multiplayer as well as multiplayer campaigns someday as well.

All in all, though, it's all very solid and very fun.  If the screenshots/videos of the ship building appeal to you at all, then this is already a must for you.  Like mercilessly blasting apart your enemy with a 12 heavy cannon behemoth, you won't regret it.

21954623.review:
This is a pretty fun games as it currently stands (as of version Alpha 8.14).

The game is as it says on the tin, design air (or land) ships in a steam punk environment, and send them against your enemies.

The design of these ships is also quite sensible, since there are lose conditions that may hit you at any point during battle for each one of your ships, which you can mitigate based on how you assembled your vehicle.
Build your ship poorly, with only one access corridor to the water supply, and you're going to have a bad time. Especially once the coal store ignites.
Run out of coal for your "suspendium" engine that keeps your airship afloat, and you will fall out of the sky.
Run out of ammo, and, welp, all those giant cannons you have there might work as a battering ram if you're lucky.
Don't have any water on board? Have fun watching the ammo store turn into a fireworks show when it inevitably catches fire!
Don't have any guards on board? Have fun letting your enemies capture the ship and turn it against you.

There are very many pieces of a ship you can use to assemble essentially whatever you can think of, provided you stay within a few specified constraints, which you can change, depending on what you can afford. Most of these restraints from what I've dealt with had to do with overloading my vessels by adding too much gun, or by trying to armor my entire tank with bricks (harder to break completely compared to metal which doesn't like to explode).

At the moment there are 2 gamemodes.

1. Combat mode, which is as you would guess. Throws you onto a blank map, where you deploy your own, and you enemies ships, duke it out and see what happens. This mode is essentially the sandbox mode of the game, as there are no financial restrictions. This is also the only mode that is currently available in multiplayer.

2. Campaign mode is a mode where the game generates a map for you and up to 12 other AI empires to face each other with reasonably good tactical battles and planning.
At the moment the campaign is a bit thread bare as the only language any empire speaks seems to be "shoot them in the face". This isn't exactly a bad thing, as the mode is quite entertaining, especially since the AI does seem to be quite competent with how it handles it's forces and resources.
Each city captured will have different resources or tech you can exploit, like cheaper wood for example, reducing the cost of wood armored ships, and maybe a different city will have the technology of flamethrowers. 
Unfortunately at the moment there is no way to steal, research, or reverse engineer tech without taking the city which contains it, but this is a flaw which I can see being fixed reasonably soon probably, considering we are still in early(ish) alpha. I've completed my first victorious large campaign in just under an hour, granted most of that time was spent designing ships to counter my enemies.

The game itself is actually very pretty considering the pixel art graphics, and can run on essentially a toaster oven.

I feel the current price of 9.99 is actually quite a reasonable price for the game with the current ammount of features present in the game, as this game is quite the time sink if you want it to be (I've probably got about 6 or more hours in offline mode that steam doesn't track). I would happily reccomend this game to anyone that asks about it.

21854763.review:
I never write reviews, I think I've written maybe 1 and I own 700+ games on Steam.  I'm writing this simply because the devs asked nicely to help them out, and seeing as how I've lost my entire night and morning playing this game, I'm obliging.  I've barely tapped the surface here, but I could spend hours and and hours designing and testing ships.  I've spent 5 hours so far on my first design.  Haven't even touched land vehicles.  I did make a huge land base building that was pretty sweet.

The different types of strategies for ships are mind-boggling.  You can create ships that have a high vertical ceiling that can then drop bombs on your enemy, or you can create a fast ship for ramming your enemy, or you could just try to get close and board the enemy.

And the multiplayer works flawlessly.  For a game that doesn't look all that awe-inspiring on the Steam Store, I'm amazed at how well everything just works.  You create a game, set a point limit, and can either choose to use a single giant flying vehicle, or a squadron of little ones, or a mix of land, air, and static buildings.  Just everything about this is so well-designed and works so flawlessly.  I'd write more, but I want to get back to editing my ship and challenging my friend to a re-match!

21448960.review:
"I got a fever, and the only prescription is more airships" -Christopher Walken

Designing:

Creating airships (landships and buildings) in this game is addicting. Probably the first "design a vehicle" type game I've played where a wall of guns wasn't superior to a wall of slightly less guns. Even in its current state every weapon, component and ship class feels useful when designed right. A battering ram can turn that dreadnaught into a dread NOT.

Fighting:

Watching those brave little men scurry about their ships is engrossing, but combat often becomes hectic enough that watching would be unwise. Tactics and placement feel as important as the designs themselves. A hefty broadside of gattling guns doesn't mean much when your enemy is sitting 200m above your ship's max service ceiling, bombs dropping.

Perhaps the most intense moments are when the ammo runs dry and it becomes a demolition derby.


The dev is very active in the community, and has probably responded to every post in the forum I've read so far. While small, the community is friendly, and is quick to schedule matches with a forum/community post.

From someone who judges Early Access titles by price vs whats currently playable, I'd reccomend a buy.

21315985.review:
A battle in Airships is kind of like this:
>they will never defeat my huge, armoured mothership with 12 cannons
>my mothership is too heavy to fly
>my mothership is being pelted with shots
>my mothership is on fire
>BAIL OUT BAIL OUT
>the ammo store exploded killing everyone on board
>send in my three smaller ships
>one loses lift
>lands on the other
>both explode
>one ship left
>out of ammo now
>it's been a pleasure serving with you gentlemen
>ram it into the opponents ammo store
>their lift balloons explode, half my ship is disintegrated
>their ship plummets downwards towards their ground fleet
>complete destruction
>i have won
>my ship runs out of coal and falls on the top of the pile of ships
>1 crew member left
>10/10 would give PTSD again

This game is great. Modestly priced with a lot of replay value. The idea is you build your own fleet of fully modular and customisable ships and try to conquer other kingdoms. Building ships is a balancing act between armour, weight, crew, firepower and speed which requires a lot of thought to get right. The combat is action packed real-time strategy. Every battle is tense and will take its toll on your ships which will lose ammo, crew, and important modules if you are not careful. Requires quick thinking and change of strategy.

21284482.review:
I would recommend this game. I am not an expert review writer, but I will try to say why I like this game.

1: COMBAT. The combat is fun and can be challenging. It also makes maneuvering the possibility between winning and failing. But maneuvering isn't the only combat important thing. You also need the right ship loadout for the right enemy, for almost every battle. There isn't any stock ship design that I know of that is capable of handling any situation. Being outnumbered is also a way to decrease chances of victory, even if you outgun the opposition.

2: SHIP DESIGN. You may have played some type of game in the past where you have a set ship shape, and possibly even systems. But in this, you have extreme control over your ship design. You can make unrealistic looking ships, cool looking ships, and any other ship shape you can thinks of. This also goes for weapons.

3: FUTURE POTENTIAL. This game has SO much potential to be one of the best 2d airship construction games out there at some point in the future. It could even be tough competition in its current state! I can't wait to see what the grand release update will be, as that is usually the biggest and best update before release from early access.

SUMMARY: This game is destined for greatness, and all you have to do is buy it. It will not be a big bother on even some of the older kinds of computers. The combat systems are great, the building system is great, what are you wating for? Its waiting for you!

(If you are still skeptical of this, just look up some of the most recent videos on the internet for this game.)

21220061.review:
I may be coming into this a bit biased due to my love of airships; but all in all in the short time I've played it I've seen the potential for this. With the tools it already provides it gives you possible hours of playtime with a well thought out (If a bit too chaotic for me) conquest mode that really expands upon the games strength; which, as you may have guessed, are the things you can create. 
      
The generic language there is important, because the game let's you make far beyond just airships. There's landships and buildings too, each of which is just as engaging to create and build as the floating beasts you normally focus on. For example, I've built the HMS One Punch (with dual giant rams) for the express purpose of destroying all of the enemy ship's faces. But just one glance at the weapons shows everything from cystalline lazer cannons to rockets, and gives any wannabe crazed engineer all the options in the world for awesome designs. However, while decorations are alright, paint in this game quite frankly looks atrocious; so honestly I just keep wood looking like wood and so on.

I've yet to try multiplayer, but it seems like it would pretty fun with friends if you establish certain rules first. The single player is more than enough to satisfy me at this point. Also, ship boarding exists, which is the single most important feature I've wanted in any airship game ever.

But is it worth it? Yes. For 10 bucks it's completely worth it so far. With proper care this game could become something borderline legendary.

21216137.review:
Here are some remarkable things about this game:
-When a ship breaks up (for example, from having its bow pinned on a floating island by one ship and having another ship come down on its stern, breaking it over the lip of the island) the part that is broken off becomes its own ship, albiet most likely lacking its own propulsion system or command staff (though not necessarily), thus putting it out of your control. This happens both when a ship is bisected and when it explodes into several large fragments.
-Marines and commandos have unbelievably good pathing for an indie game. You can have several ships in  row in deadlock with enemy ships (where your ships are equals signs and enemy ships are minuses: ====-----) and tell the soldiers in your rearmost ship to board an enemy ship, and the men will exit their ship, get on its roof and walk or jump along all ships in the intermediate distance (friendly and enemy) if doing so allows them to reach their target. If an enemy ground installation has an island directly above it preventing close access, you can position yourself above the island and your men can jump from your ship onto the island, and then from the island onto the building. The island isn't a static movement zone, just a piece of terrain that's loosely classified as a ship. Incredible.
-Ground walker mechs have highly adaptable footwork. I regularly see walker mechs climb on top of friendly and enemy landships in the course of movement, in fact this can be used to bridge otherwise impassible terrain. One time I saw a two-legged mech balance both feet atop a tree stump in the middle of combat.
-Anything can be built from tiny mail blimps and little interceptors to kilometer-long battlecruisers super heavy dreadnoughts with hundreds of visible men aboard (these are legal in multiplayer while playing 10k-limit games, it should be noted) from the same component parts (of which there are many, many).

As you can see this is an incredibly deep, dynamic and potent game. Because it can be hard to tell whether somebody loves a game or just enjoys tinkering with it in their own particular way, here is a list of well-known and excellent games I've played recently but had less fun doing so than I did with Airships:
Pillars of Eternity
L.A. Noire
Broforce
XCOM: Enemy Within
Prison Architect

I hope that Airships will become the low-key genesis of a famous AAA series to-be, similar to the relatively humble origins of Grand Theft Auto, Fallout, the Elder Scrolls and so forth. 10/10.

21055589.review:
Great game, all around!

Airships is mostly a real time strategy game, with resource managing elements. I have not played the multiplayer very much, but the single player is some of the most fun to be had with 10$ that you'll ever find!

The graphics are neat pixel art, and available in a wide range of resolutions. Very crisp, though sometimes the colors can be a little bland (menus and such tend to be all brown or black, which is to be expected of the genre yes, but perhaps a little higher contrast would make things easier to see).

Gameplay is extremely solid. I've only encountered extremely mild bugs (a certain airship design never replaced the cannon when repaired, I had to refit it with one every time). You use the mouse to select commands for the airships (usually just movement) and this can seem simplistic at first, but quickly gets hectic once you start having more than 6 ships in a battle at the same time, which is by no means a bad thing! (protip: try to manuever your ships so that when one goes down, it doesnt take 3 others directly below with it, causing a massive fiery explosion destroying half your fleet).

sound deisign is spot on, weapons have varying sound effects that allow you to tell what is being fired by listening alone, music is good, though there's only like 3 different songs in the whole game. You don't really notice this though, as i'd liken it to the hangar building music in Kerbal Space Program; just sort of there, not really in the forground.

Some changes i'd love to see would be a custom sizing option for the menus, with the building menu sometimes it's difficult to select which module you want (at least on my 1080p screen, not sure about smaller resolutions). It would also be wonderful to see some more offline modes, perhaps having only a single airship and upgrading in order to complete tasks or something. 
And finally, I would love to be able to personally change which workers do what, or at least assign them myself. for example, if I have 6 airshipmen, an ammo depot (4 workers max), two cannons (1 worker each) and a water tank (2 workers max), the game will automatically decide where the workers go. so i might have 2 workers on the water tank, two for the cannons, and two for the ammo depot. But sometimes i'd rather have 3 on the depot, and only 1 on the water tank. nitpicky perhaps, but it would help a little.

overall fantastic game, extremely enjoyable. Nothing glaringly wrong. Definitely a positive mark on the tarnished steampunk genre of games.

Ein grandioses Spiel für jeden Fan von gigantischen feuerspuckenden Luftschiffen und anderen verrükten Kreationen der nicht ganz so historischen Kriegsführung. Es ist ein wunderbarer, noch unverbrauchter Stil, der hier in zufälligen, immer wieder motivierenden Kampangnen dargestellt wird. Die Grafik ist einfach, aber stimmig und einfach solide umgesetzt, genau wie das Gameplay. Das Erstellen der Kriegsmaschinen allein ist schon beschäftigung genug, aber sie dann auch noch auf dem Schlachtfeld eingesetzt zu sehen, das ist wirklich fantastisch. Zumal die Vielfalt möglicher Kreationen beachtlich ist. Ob in der Luft, am Boden oder als stationäre Verteidigung, in jeder Position können verschiedenste Waffen- und Verteidiungssysteme eingesetzt werden. Jedes Spiel lässt sich mit leicht unterschiedlichen Strategien der kohlebetriebenen Kriegsführung gewinnen - der Wiederspielwert ist dadurch unglaublich groß. 

Dieses Spiel hat nicht nur großes Potential einmal ein großartiger fertiger Titel zu werden, es ist jetzt schon ein solides Spiel, und seinen Preis, gerade im Vergleich zu anderen Early Access Titeln dieser Preiskategorie, in jedem Fall wert! 
Auch wenn es noch nicht fertig ist, einen ganzen Haufen spaßiger Spielstunden hat man garantiert!

20942712.review:
So far, this gme has been great. 
The core mechanic is desgning the most effective ship. Simple concept, right? But from that point, the world opens up with all the possible strategies; ramming, boarding, sniping, bombing, heavy slow fire or fast light fire. 

WhatI really enjoy about this game is that the devs know what they are doing. With these sort of building games, its usually easiest to just make a hulking juggernaut that wipes everything out. While this was the first thing I tried, I realized even this was pretty difficult. The game was balanced so that the larger your ship is, the more difficult it is to distribute resources and fly quickly. This held true for all the other facets of the game; no strategy is the best outright.

This game is amazing for early access. all I can think of to improve upon is a better UI, and maybe a map editor. It would also be cool if the weapon sprites appeared on the outside view of the ship. Also, making the air balloon module circular and the leg sprites more interesting would be cool; overall, not many huge changes.

20781495.review:
Build a ship
Have no idea what you are doing and then watch it: 
burst into flames
crash
burn (a longer term version of burst)
explode
become a block of swiss cheese (or possibly a holy vessel)
be captured by the opposing team (and used against you to great affect)
be crushed by a bigger ship
be outmanuevered by a smaller one
your entire crew die off one sad lonely man at a time
and then rinse and repeat until you forget its 4 in the morning and you have work in 30 minutes

This is a clever well thought thru game with a developer who has taken a game concept that could so easily be cliche and turned into somthing truely unique and enjoyable.

(side note) Multiplayer is essentialy a dead space where you are always alone despite knowing there must be others.  You won't miss them and they may show up and say hi before tearing your ship to bits in the future.

This game also has a strong focus on the singleplayer gameplay. You are set in a small, medium or large world with respective war waging factions. All trying to get control over the various strongholds/cities and build the best fleet in the world. 

Pros:

Cons:

This game is constant fun for me and my friends, we build ships and then battle them against each other most commonly in fleets of mini bombers and spider walkers with gatling guns all over. The whole point of this game is to build a airship/tank/walker/spider walker/fortress and use it against your friends or any one else who dare challenge you not even to mention the single player which isn't some generic story of bad guys vs. good guys its a match against AI that aren't easy to get rid of(when you're starting out and have to think of efficient ship designs). The AI flank you attack you were you are weakest and even fight over certain areas that provide advanced weaponry which you can attack yourself and gain the ability to use rockets or flamethrowers etc. The AI is amazing because certain AI empires use the same tactic against you and you can use that against them while others will learn new tactics as they defeat empires or form alliances. I don't exactly know why but I seem to take the negatice reviews for this game as sort of a personal insult either for my love of this game or the massive ammount of respect I have for the lone developer which has created this amazing game and continues to support and change it all by himself.


I loved and still Love this game , but I thought my love had ended when my hard drive on my computer died a while back and I had to get a new one I thought all my ships were gone until I went on the game and found all my ships in perfect condition, just marvelous. From my point of view those who dislike this game just don't see either it's great potential and progress through early acess or they're just complaining that you only play the game once and never play it again. Those who say that they'll never play the game again just don't realize the almost endless potential that mods for the game hold because this game can become something else, admittingly like alot of other games. 


--Important note for all those who have or are thinking of getting this game--

In the settings there is an option to allow the AI to use the ships you've built, trust me it changes the game alot.

19638981.review:
There are many small things I would improve about this game if I could have my wish, but most of them simply boil down to wanting more of it. More modules, bigger battles, longer campaigns, more detailed tech tree, etc.

At the end of the day, it's a early access indie title that only costs $10 USD, so you have to be a bit realistic about what is possible. In that mindset it has a lot going for it: 

1. I've not encountered any noticeable bugs
2. It runs fine on a laptop not built for gaming 
3. Gameplay is fairly straightforward to learn and amenable to both casual and intense playstyles
4. Game balance is reasonable with multiple viable strategies
5. The developer is [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/zarkonnen/posthistory/]very approachable[/url] with plenty of interesting and attainable ideas for the future

Content-wise (as of v7.4), you're looking at about 15 to 20 hours worth of gameplay value for a singleplayer-only experience if you have only a modest interest in ship design. If you happen to have a friend or two for regular multiplayer sessions or happen to really love designing things just to watch them explode, I can easily see that going upwards of 40 hours.

------

Even if you're not convinced this is for you, it is worth watching for future updates. The game seems to only get better with age.

19559125.review:
It took me a while to work out why I find this game so fascinating but now I've got it:  the 'deep zoom' effect.

So what do I mean by this?

Level 1:  
At the highest level you have a fairly typical, but stylish, campaign map that shows a birds eye view of the world, oceans, continents and islands etc.  

Level 2: 
Within these landmasses you have a number of cities each of which you can conquer and expand.  Click on a city and you are presented with side-on view of the city surrounds and any buildings, airships and landships located there.  

Level 3: 
Each vehicle has a distinctive, often animal like, shape and can have 'scary' looking warpaint.  The shape of the vehicle is a direct result of what it actually needs to successfully move and operate.  Nothing you see is pointless.

Level 4:
Now, zoom in to one of the vehicles and notice the individual rooms, with corridors and ladders connecting them.  It's like a little city within each vehicle.

Level 5:
Pick one of the rooms and zoom in further and you can see tiny men actually operating the weapons, transferring coal/ammo from stores, putting out fires, reparing armour, resting in berths, using repair rooms, controlling the vehicle etc.  

Now realise each of these men is essential to the operation of the vehicle but can be killed in battle. Amazing!


Pros:

* Such an original game, there is nothing else like it.

*  Great feeling of controlling an empire of hundreds of fantasy war machines and thousands of poor little men needed to operate them. 

*  Nice flexibiliy to play battles as a fast action game or a slower tactical game thanks to the time controls and spacebar to pause.  
 
* Excellent feedback on what is actually happening during a battle thanks to 'speech bubbles' from your men when the vehicle takes damage, fires break out,  crew-members die, the battle is lost/won etc.

* If you don't like the built-in vehicle designs, design your own using the in-game designer and see if you can do any better.  You can also design and build static buildings (ie fortresses) and these are essential for defending a city.

* Really unique and stylish presentation style for an indie game.  The typeface, colour scheme, campaign map graphical design and UI style are all very well done.  

* Music soundtrack is stirring and suits the theme of the game perfectly.
 
Cons:

*  Still in EA/alpha so there are a few performance issues with large battles, but the developer is aware of these and is looking to fix them asap.

* There are not many players playing multiplayer games at present.  I play single player only and love it, but if you need multiplayer you may want to wait to see if the community really grows.

* Some minor UI issues but these might just be my own preferences.
 

In summary, highly recommended.

19541486.review:
I reviewed this game a while back and i said that it was really good then. It has only improved since then and I feel like I should write another review. This is absolutely one of my favorite games and I cant reccommend it enough to anyone who likes steampunk themed, pixelated, warfare. 

The vehicle editor is easy to use and great fun to experiment with, between airships landships and buildings there are plenty of strategies for crushing the enemy. 

Multiplayer is a lot of fun too. I admit Ive only used the LAN multiplayer with my brother but it works great, I only wish that the vehicle price limit could be higher than 10,000. (EDIT it now goes to 100,000)

As far as combat there are two ways to play, single battles where you set up both sides for testing out new or modified creations. The other is conquest mode, you get a choice of map size and AI difficulty before you begin, the conquest maps are different every time and each city you capture offers bonuses allowing you to cunstruct new ships. The AI can be very aggressive or very defensive but once you figure out which they are its a lot of fun to adapt a strategy to try and beat them. 

In combat everything works really well. Its very rewarding to see airships I designed blowing apart enemy airhips. The explosions are fantastic by the way, I love the way burning debris falls to the ground after a room explodes. I suppose my only real complaints would be that I would like a button to slow dowwn time because giving orders quickly when Ive got eight different Ships is hard, and Id like the combat zone to be longer so I can give my first set of orders before the enemy starts raining shells on me.

Each weapon has its own pros and cons so they dont all feel the same, not everyweapon wil work for every situation either which is nice, keeps me thinking. The armor system is also done well, better armor is heavier so theres a tradeoff between durability and speed/lift.

The developer is great, super active with news about updates and how the game is progressing. Updates somtimes feel far apart but thats because each update contains a multitude of new features and improvments and so far Ive found no bugs in the game either.

So  Ill just say it one more time, this game is awesome! It has continued to get better and better and Im really excited for the next update too. I give this game a 10/10 and reccommend it to anyone and everyone.

19473724.review: 10/10! Exactly what it says on the tin, and still updating! I greatly look forward to the final version of the game. In its current state? DEFINITELY worth the price of admission.

19438996.review:
自分だけのエアシップ（+ランドシップ）を作って戦ったり、世界を制覇したりするゲーム。
PVからは取っつきにくそうな臭いがプンプンするが、チュートリアルからやれば最低でもちゃんと飛ぶ船が作れるのでそこまで難しくはない。

コンクエストモードではランダム生成のマップと帝国で領土を奪い合う。
常に新しい船を作っていかなければならないので、かなり忙しい。
既存の船もあるが、やはり自分の船をガンガンデザインして戦地に投入していくのがこのゲーム最大の楽しみと言える。

【良い点】

・ゼロから船を生み出すので、なんでも自由に組み合わせられる所。色々積みすぎて飛ばない船を作ってしまう事も。
・演出が派手。大量の船同士の戦いは圧巻（2Dゲームにしてはそこそこのスペックが要求される）
・戦車や多脚メカも作れる

【悪い点】
・クルーの動きが自動なので、戦略性はあまり高くない。
・船が指示した通りに動かない事がある。あとよく地形にスタックする。
・大量の船で処理が重くなる。戦闘の倍速ボタンがあるが、処理が重い時に押すと大変な事になる。
・コンクエストモードが簡素。船のデザインと建築、侵略、防衛、以外にできる事はあまりない。


まだストレスフルな面が多々あるが、作った船を戦わせるに当たって大きな問題はない。
コンクエストモードは進めていくと武器やパーツが増えていくので、現状でも十分楽しめる出来。

レビューが軒並み好評なのを見ると、やはり好きな人はとことん好きなゲームだと思う。
セール歴は無いので気になった人は即、買い。

19388837.review:
Hugely enjoyable game with near unlimited replayability.

The art style is relatively simple but lends itself well to the game. The game shines in its mechanics and depth of detail (each crew member and is modeled with his/her own duties, ship systems such as coal, ammo and water run in real time, if you lose a significant portion of your crew certain systems will be resource starved). 

The particle effects are amazing and it's so satisfying taking in the battle damage endured by your airship/vehicle in a smoke filled sky above the burning remains of your enemy.

Initally from youtube videos I was under the impression it was a turn-based game but this is not the case. It is very much real time. The cool down timer for giving commands to your ship (longer the bigger your ship is, can be shortened by adding bridge/cockpit modules) adds an extra dimension to battles where planning and preemptive positioning are rewarded.

The game has its rough edges but is supported by an active developer with plans for new features in the future such as adding monsters and random encounters in conquest among other things.

Conclusion: Great game with an enjoyable multiplayer. The community is small but once it grows it will be perfect.

For only 10$ is a great game, there are land and air vehicles, and you can even construct buildings, and they are all great, you can even make tanks and bipedal land vehicles.

After some more airships battles I see that some of the problems I listed were my own fault. This is still early alpha and the developer is clearly working hard on sorting out problems. I just wanted to quickly change this review to positive because I was a little unfair in the previous one. Once I have more time, I will go back and remove the misinformation.

Old Review: 
I am running this game on Ubuntu, and it is basically unplayable. I don't know if other operating systems have these problems, but they make the game infuriating for me to play. Half of my airships refuse to move even though there is nothing around them they could collide with. The game also locks up randomly at times, and when I alt-tab my entire os is unresponsive. Another issue, unrelated to bugs, is that the computer seems to win stalemeates. If I run out of ammo during a fight in conquest mode and the computer does as well, it is content to sit there until I flee. I think the captain on defense should at win in these cases and not allow the ai to have free wins. If these problems are fixed, the game seems very enjoyable, but in its current state I cannot recommend it.

So far the game seems to be on the right path.
There are just some things this game 'gets right', and for Early Access, I'd say she run fairly smooth.
Get an idea of what you want to build. A small cutter, assualt ship, or land ship to deliver marines to enemy ships and structures and take them for yourself? Or maybe a massive flying castle wich mainly sits in one spot and blows everything apart. Then, build it. Seriously, its that simple. You can even sit there and paint it up to look nice too if you want.
Astheticly, this game is pleaseing. You get the steampunk vibe right away, when your first makeing your coat of arms. As  the combat takes off you realize you didnt give your airship enough lift, or that your landship cant take a hill to save it's life. So you take that design and refurbish it, and try again. Now you realize airships are tearing your landships apart, so you start to tack AA guns on every single build. 
Meanwhile dureing the fighting, one of your cannons hits thiere coal store, and they catch fire. Unable to fuel vital systems they crash and explode spectacularly.
2D and pixilated, yes, but it works for this game.  I avoid this game now dureing the work week, because I know how addictive it is, and how much time will vanish before I shut it down.
Keep up the goood work devs, cant wait to see more.

17457809.review: Most early access games have left me wishing I hadn't wasted my time. This game is one of only two exceptions. Airships: Conquer the Skies takes elements from various other games and genres. You build, somewhat similarly to Minecraft. You see battles and command your machines in 2D, like a sidescroller. You build and manage an empire, like a strategy game. And it all takes place in an original steampunk setting. All of these elements have been blended together so well, nothing feels disjointed or distracting. The graphics are pixelly and can run with ease on low-spec computers, but are not bad. They are what they are intended to be, and I thoroughly enjoy them. The game is getting consistent work from its developer, and I have no fear that the final product will not deliver in every way. Basically, I can't recommend this game enough, whether you like steampunk, a little strategy, building and unleashing war machines, or just want to try something unique.

17064064.review:
A incredibly fun  game with loads of options for airship/landship/fortess building.

This game is a really great sandbox for anyone who loves airships, pixely explosions, designing death machines, and conquering lands with fleets of airships in all forms (and landships).
It features a solid designer for building and optimising your own classes of air- and landships with a good choice of modules avaible. There are virtually no constraints on your creativity, whether you want to slay your foes with masses of tiny airships, have huge colossi butcher enemy fleets or board the enemy ships to add them to your arsenal, you can have it! 
There is even a multiplayer, so grab a friend and challenge them!

Steam workshop support is also avaible for the newest dev build, so you can share your creations and create own weapons. 

Unfortunatley it's quite unlikely that you will be able to play multiplayer with some random person, because few play it, but the conquest mode offers enough replayability for me.

I really recommend buying Airships, it is fun, it is quite cheap, and it has a really active developer.

Замечательная игра про захват городов при помощи летающий кораблей (с последних апдетов и при помощи наземной техники)!
+ Можно построить свой корабль и использовать его в игре!
+ Нехило умный нпс! ( Пришел ты такой с целой флотилией на вражеский город, а тебя разгромил маленький кораблик захватив все твои корабли путём "На абордаж!")
+ Система экономики. ( Каждый твой город даёт прибыль, и разумеется содержание кораблей будет уменьшать твою прибыль, а также твоя прибыль будет уменьшаться с кол-вом зданий в твоих городах)
+ Мультиплеер! (По моему мнению очень скучный, это как пойти на захват одного города только не против ИИ, а против человека, а про карту можете забыть)
+ Разнообразие врагов. ( Не все ИИ одинаковы, у каждого своя тактика и разные корабли, так что будьте всегда начеку!)
+ Разработчики хоть и редко, но добавляют довольно хорошие нововведения.
- Слишком легко! ( Трудно бывает только на первый трёх играх, а потом начинаешь понимать как побеждать, вот я например за 10 мин прошел самую большую карту) (Опять же с последних апдейтов стало чуть сложнее и появилось больше настроек сложности, но игра так или иначе игру ты пройдёшь быстро)
- Маленькие карты. ( Ну как-то слишком быстро все захватываешь...)
- Оптимизация заметно ухудшается... Мне пришлось вообще забыть об ускорении времени во время боя, ибо -1 ФПС.

Эй ты, что смотришь? Быстрее хватай эту игру!

Really good game! 

Can't wait for it to be finished. 

Pros:
-Let you Military and Asthetic creativity Run Free. Flying Forts? Beutiful Ships that look lovely while on fire? Bombers that can't get more than 20 meters off the ground? You see it, you build it, you realise it doesn't work and you improve. Great for replayability and Fun!

-All ships and Building have weaknesses. Built an amazing flying fort that's basically immune to all weapons and can keep flying basically forever? Lol you just got rammed by a fireship and are now buring falling out of the sky.

-Varied Combat

Cons/Would be cool:
-Sometimes Crashes but that doesn't become a problem if you safe often. AutoSave Feature would be great! 

-Campaign Map could be a bit more complex and a few more features regarding economy,defence and happiness could be added. 

-Experience for Ship Crew would be 10/10, would stop me just scrapping amazing ships that have been to hell and back that i've become attached to. 

- "Technologies" could be researched/ stolen/ reverse engineered from captured vessels. 

-More Diffuculty in taking over cities and more diversity in types of cities you're taking over. E.g a captitol cities or larger cities  could be bessieged/ bombed to reduce the defences of that city. This would make taking this more of an achievement. 

-War would cost rescources not just money. Not enough steel for ship aromour? Gotta use wood. Your faction is having a coal Shortage due to your vast fleets? Your fleet is now grounded and unable to move far.

Overal a really good game with amazing potential, I can't wait to see where it goes!
9/10

This is one of the most adorable and amazing Indie games i have ever seen and bought. If you liked Crazy Machines as a child, or dream of Steampunk Airships, or just like really deep strategized Building and Fighting games... read no further. Just wishlist it - or buy immediately.

The Developer, Zarkonnen, is fully behind the project and keeps adding high-quality, well-balanced and major content patches and visual improvements into the game. The last patches included weapons, more varied backgrounds and a dynamic light engine as well as loads of fixes and improvements.

Plans for additions include: Ground combat, new Engines/propulsion mechanisms, Walkers and Tanks, Map Objectives and so on.

This already is - and will become even moreso - an amazing game. Too bad it has gained so little attention. I had to comb really hard through the internet to find it, and if you made it here, I bet you did too.

It was worth it.

I <3 This game.

15937186.review:
I bought this game because I wanted "something wigh a piece of steampunk in it" and could not find anything my PC would be able to run. And I'm sure it is worth the money.

Build your own airship!
First and the most obvious thing to mention - you can build almost anything from small funny coal-burner to an uncrashable flying fortres. There is a very comfortable editor in game and rules and limitations are simple and balanced. Besides, u can build a tower in singleplayer and there is a developement of landships (man says will be out this month).

Crash your own airship!
Physics in this game is made just alright for having a lot of fun smashing your coal-burner into some tree or splitting (and crashing) your uncrashable fortress in half over some flying piece of rock.

Crash others!
Cannons, rifles, grenades, more cannons, powder rockets, machine guns and other nasty stuff will help you reduce enemy to dust! And if you can't shoot it, you most possible are able to ram it or capture! Both are a lot of fun usually))
Singleplayer is fine but becomes boring sooner or later. Dev says he will fix it someday.
Multiplayer is fun! Nothing besides short fights makes it some kind of sport. I have played hours and will play more!)

Crash the Developer!
...and be pround of it xD

Active development!
The guy has a forum where anyone can ask for some feature and if it is accepted by the community and is not against the development plan, it will be included in the update. It's cool. Sadly, there is no modding support for now, but the updates bring new stuff, so it's ok.

Fun!
Among other stuff, you may see: big battles, small battles, a ship you were building for an hour is falling apart because you pressed a wrong button, small cute men run around your ship, small cute men killing each other on your/enemy's ship, small cute men jump from one ship to another accidently falling (wich is even more fun), small cute men dying in agony all around your ship/fortress, firethrowers (yes, baby), meet cool men in glorious battles high in the sky, crash two (or more) big airships into each other, annoy the dev about updates and new features (and if this you can do anywhere, ...), see those updates and new features! The list could go on, but...

I'm tired of writing this!
So I'll just say try it! It does not cost much anyway =)

15890997.review: I get a lot of glee from playing Airships. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Vraiment Fun a jouer dans un univers steampunk bien élaboré !

Ce jeu est pour l'instant en accès anticipé, mais le developpeur étant à l'écoute des clients, attendez-vous à ce que de nouvelles options apparaissent à chaque mises à jour. Le jeu est d'ailleurs pleinement jouable en l'état et les quelques bugs mineurs ne gênent en rien le fonctionnement du programme.

Vous avez envie de construire des aéronefs immenses ou des défenses terrestres impressionnantes : passez par l'éditeur intégré et faites fonctionner votre imagination !

Les graphismes "old school" sont clairs et bien pensés et même si le côté "carré" vous dérange un peu, une fois dans la bataille, vous n'y prêterez plus attention !

Les Plus :
- Editeur d'aéronefs et de bâtiments à base de modules intégré ( + différentes peintures et blindages disponibles)
- Combats dynamiques air-air er air-sol avec capture possible
- Affrontements multijoueurs fonctionnels

Les Moins :
- Les campagnes solo ne sont "pour le moment" que des attaques ou des défenses de villes
- Pas de tutoriel pour l'instant mais quelques "Let's play" pourront faire l'affaire


Chargez les canons, votre Empire n'attend que vous !

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Really Fun to play in a well elaborated steampunk universe !

This game is actually in early access, but given that the dev listening customers, expect new options appear on every update. Anyway the game is fully playable as is and the few minor bugs will not interfere with the functioning of the program.

You want to build huge airships or impressive terrestrial defenses : use the in-game editor and put your imagination to work !

"Old school" graphics are sharp and well thought out and even if the "square" design troubles you, once in battle, you will focus no more on this !

Pros :
- In-game airships and building editor working with modules (+ different paints and armours available)
- Dynamical battles air-air and air-ground with the possibility of capturing
- Functional multiplayer fights

Cons :
- Solo campaigns are just "for the moment" attacks or defenses of cities
- No tutorial for now but a few "let's play" can make the deal


Load the cannons, your Empire awaits you !

15182053.review:
I might be a little biased (I wrote the music for Airships: Conquer the Skies), but I will say that I have enjoyed playing this game ever since I first got a chance to try an early (pre-Steam!) copy. Designing your own Airships is a really fun experience, and seeing how well your ideas match up in real battles makes this game, at least for me, a very addictive experience. I’m still pretty bad at actual combat, but I’ve enjoyed trying to “out design” the enemy. I’ve always wanted to know what an RTS would be like if *I* could design the units, and with Airships, I get the answer. 

Its worth mentioning that this is an Early Access game. I’ve scored a few of these games, and while I’ve seen a lot of customers who are really happy with Early Access, I know some people prefer to wait. With the pace that David Stark (the main dev) is updating Airships, I think we all see a promising future, but if you are looking for the final, complete Airships experience, you might want to wait. Having said that, the Airships that I’ve played on Steam is quite different from the Airships that I played when David Stark and I first talked about the score— this guy is serious about keeping the game updated, and working toward a solid, finished product. For me, Airships: Conquer the Skies is already worth a try, and I’ve had a fun time playing it, especially in its Early Access state.

I’m really proud to have been able to work on this title, and I’m excited to see it here on Steam. If it seems like something you’d be into, the price simply can’t be beat. 

…I also hear the score is really good too :)

10/10 would write a score for this again.

14717605.review:
Excellent game, if you like Gratuitous Space Battles, you'll probably like this.
~No limits in ship design other than the maximum crew size.
~Partly controllable battles, with an interesting mechanic of control through bridges and cockpits on your ships. For example, if you have a cockpit for a giant ship, you might only be able to issue commands every 30 seconds, but if you have a bunch of bridges for a small ship, you can issue commands very quickly.
~Crew mechanics are interesting, your crew members can be wounded and then taken to a sickbay to recover. They also quite clearly move around the ship doing various tasks, such as feed coal into the engines, running engines, aiming guns, reloading guns, commanding the ship (from the bridge or cockpit), repairing the ship, defending the ship from invaders, and many more things (too many to list).
~A campaign thing that is a bit simple at the moment, although the dev is working on making it more interesting.
~Ship customization
~Realistic Heraldry, which affects your ships though some bonuses depending on what you choose.
These are just a few of the many good points of this game. The dev is very open about what he will be changing and adding to the game, he is also very active. One of the few indie games that has a dev who cares about their game.
Unfortunately, the community at the time of this review, is very small, almost no one plays the online gamemode at the moment, but I am sure if the community grew, it could be very interesting to see PVP.

This is one nice suprise of a realy good Early Access Game. Arishps: Conquer The Skies combines a good strategy game with all the fun of building your own kind of fleet.  Even it is an early access game is already good for playing and makes a lot of fun. I can't wait to see the finished game and all of its new coming features. 

About the game itself. You are playing a nation starting with a small city on the map. You can choose between different map sizes (small, medium, large) and you mainly control your fleet over this map. Then you can start bulding a Airship in the city and construct one by yourself. A plus point here is that you actually don't need a tutorial because there are a lot of helpful information within the game and game itsel is good to handle.

If you want to built your own Airship you need a lot of different modules so that your ship can acutally fly or shoot...Moreover think about the money. A complex high armored Battleship is nice but it is actually even better when you have the money to bulit it ^^..So you always have to think about to balance between Airships, Money and Defense. So actually you can very, rebuilt, refit your ships or defense structure which is really nice and brings a lot of varity in the game. 

What more is there so say......

Airships: Conquer the Skies is one of the few really good Early Access games. So far it is working fine and makes a lot fun. I can't find any serious bugs or problems within the game. For everybody who always has dreamt about building his own nation with a fleet of own constructed Airships and crush them against your enemies this game is a must have.

14649675.review:
First impressions, played for about an hour. Pretty good for a £7 early access game. 

PROS:
- Insane ship customisation, seems like 100+ parts (and this is only the first public release) some of which are decorative, utility, or weapons. You can have things like a sickbay, crew quarters, various armours, different cannons and propellors on a tiny or huge ship. Or you can glue a giant dick banner on the side of it. 

- Pretty intense, epic combat. My eyes hurt from watching various cannon balls and shrapnel fly around everywhere, ships falling out of the sky and exploding on the ground, swashbuckling crewmates boarding enemy ships via flimsy ropes and watching your little guys run around inside your ships fixing things and dying. Amazing.

CONS:
 - Although you build little defensive structures around your cities, they are basically just the same as ships except they can't move. No advantage really to investing in these, might as well build more ships.

- Battles seem to last about 45 seconds, even the largest ships run out of ammo very quickly and its annoying how often ships will just seemingly explode after taking one hit. 

- Very limited single player campaign at the moment, just about 6 or 7 cities on a map which can be easily taken by 2 or 3 ships. I pretty much beat it in 10 mins. 

- Picking certain things for your custom banner will actually determine which perks you get, meaning that you have to pick the icons for what perks you want, meaning you cant actually make the banner you want because you wont get the best perks. Don't really see a reason for this, just make the perks a seperate thing. 

OVERALL , this game is really fun so far, the cons are things that seem like easy fixes to me (just rebalance ammo and add more defense structure parts) if you like games like Pixel Pirates or SPAZ, this game is for you. The simple pixel graphics might not be for everyone but if you can get past that this game has some potential.

14648777.review:
Now this is what early access should be about. 
Not unfinished sheit, but unfinished greatness with flaws.

http://youtu.be/qWytQCkLFP4

The game revolves around as the title would spoil to you, airships. *gasp* 
Designing airships, building airships, flying airships, fighting other airships with you're airships, destroying enemy bunkers with airships, defending you're empire with airships and invading other empires with airships.

Did I mention the airships? 

You can create almost anything with the tools you've been given, want a cheap ship with a bunch cheap guns? Rifle it up! If you want some more uumpf then cannons and bomb bay doors will do the trick.
Or if you are a brute you can just ram you're ship against the other ones.

Of course you can't build a ship with a ton of guns and ammo and expect it to fly very well without a bunch of lift and propulsion modules which you have to take into consideration while building them.
Crew is also important for everything from getting the ammo to the guns and operating them, or controlling fires and helping wounded comrades to the sickbay if needed.

The other limiting factor of you're imagination is naturally the cost of the airships and the bank vault of you're empire.
If you want bigger ships, then you must invade the other nations of the world and destroy the defensive buildings and airships stationed there. Which in turn makes the empire bigger and more cash come in from the newly acquired cities.

Be careful though! If you take your fleet into the enemy city and you yourself haven't produced any defensive buildings for the protection of you're citizens, the enemy can and will take you're city.
This way the game also has small strategical elements to it.

There is also a multiplayer mode but I haven't been able to try that as of yet, but I can imagine people coming up with all kinds of amazing airships to destroy one another.

Graphics are cute but at times its hard to make sense on what's going on because of them.

This is still in early access so if you absolutely don't purchase these things then don't but this game is in my opinion a diamond compared to other stuff that early access has given us.


So I absolutely do recommend this game even in it's incomplete form.

You don't need Multiplayer to have a good time, i say this because i'm a Single-Player person.


My Cons are mostly related to the AI in Conquest mode:
> Sometimes it can go berserk and conquest everything in a matter of a few minutes, usually the problem is the bonus, the most dangerous, i think, is the one that builds everything at twice the speed, mixed with Heavy Canon it's insane lol.

A story mode would be cool. Something where you start alone, join (or not) a militia or kingdom while progressively build your ship would be funny. Think about something like Mount&Blade.

It needs trading cards, the sales would increase a lot and give more visibility.

8.5/10 game, what a pearl, needs more visibility on Steam.

39005487.review:
Excellent game with massive potential,

for now its mostly combat orientated, in the future it looks like we will have more options for building cities that add revenue thus making your cities more valuable.

You can build crazy designs and the combat is really fun.

I wish that there would be weapons added that can be added to the center of the ship, that does not need a clear line of sight, as you must place weapons mostly in the front or the back, some broad side weapons would be appriciated, however the modding community is massive which offers almost everything, including battleship parts etc.

This game is a gem.

There are a few downsides,
large maps are horrible on preformance, not optimised at all, even though I have a ryzen 1800x with nividia 1080 ti, and I still get MASSIVE lags.

The cities for now are mostly strongholds, they have no economic value whatsoever, nothing produces wealth besides its capture, no option to buiild factories or farms, anything you build, which are basically defences, will actually cost you.

I end up razing every city I capture and only building strongholds on the frontiers of my empire.

Some weapons preform poorly, such as the grand ram or flamethrowers, which would need tweaking.


But overall, a great game and highly recommendable. You will not regret the purchase.
